thoughts.content: To address the user's question, I’ll explain the construction of functors with coefficients. First, there’s the quasi-functor KT^m(-; N) with coefficients in a matrix N, which represents a nonnegative column-finite matrix. I need to detail the process, starting with a homological functor and iterating a mapping cone construction with the matrix. I'll also mention the universal coefficient sequence, which links the group G to an exact sequence involving KT^m. This is key to showing agreement with algebraic topology examples.

The construction agrees with the standard definition of coefficients through tensor and Tor. They also generalize to presentations in Theorem 4.6.5, proving the independence of the chosen presentation, meaning we eventually obtain the functor KT^m(-; G) for an abelian group G. In topology, they apply this construction to homotopy functors (π_n) and show that the results fit into exact sequences. They also address limitations of the quasi-functor, which later become a strict functor. Further, this might relate to reduced homology and K-theory, with a need to open relevant content for verification.

[L177] If C is a triangulated ategory, a homologial funtor K : C ! A is a funtor whose target ategory

[L181] Many funtors that give rise to long exat sequenes at on ategories that are not triangulated, for
[L182] example, the usual homotopy funtors on the ategory of pointed topologial spaes, the K-theory
[L183] funtors, and redued homology funtors on the ategory of pointed CW-omplexes. Hene, we should
[L184] extend the notion of a homologial funtor to inlude all these examples.
[L185] Given a homologial funtor K, the funtor K with oeÆients in an abelian group is often onstruted in
[L186] order to perform more omputations or derive new results. Some appliations of funtors with oeÆients
[L187] are provided in setion 1.2.
[L188] The goal of this thesis is to provide a framework for de ning funtors with oeÆients that an be applied
[L189] to many examples. There are two reasons for undertaking this pro jet:
[L190] 1. We an use the ommon framework to gain a better understanding of a wide range of homologial
[L191] funtors.
[L192] 2. In situations where no satisfatory de nition of funtors with oeÆients has been disovered, our
[L193] framework might suggest a possible approah.
[L194] 1.2 Some appliations of homologial funtors with oeÆients
[L195] In this setion, we list some appliations of homologial funtors with oeÆients to illustrate the usefulness of studying suh funtors.
[L196] 1.2.1 Real and omplex topologial K-theory with oeÆients
[L197] A reent paper by Berrik & Matthey [6℄ uses real topologial K-theory of C-algebras to onstrut a
[L198] strongly torsion generated group with spei ed abelian groups as its integral homology groups up to

[L202] th integral homology group Hq (S) for 2  q  n. In [5℄, reasons

[L212] In [6℄, it is shown that if abelian groups A; B ; C; D; E are spei ed, one an always onstrut a strongly
[L213] torsion generated group S whose entre is isomorphi to A and whose higher integral homology up to

[L215] using a real C-algebra EA whose real topologial K-theory is losely related to A (see setion 3 of [6℄).
[L216] In this thesis, we de ne real topologial K-theory with oeÆients in any olumn- nite matrix of nonnegative integers. It turns out that the real topologial K-theory of EA is the same as the real topologial

[L622] 1.6 The approah we adopt
[L623] Based on the disussion thus far, we devise the following approah to de ning funtors with oeÆients:
[L624] 1. Let a ategory C be given. Assume that C has oning sequenes and that it is possible to de ne
[L625] multipliation by a olumn- nite matrix with nonnegative integer entries in C. Assume further that
[L626] there is a given homologial funtor K with ertain good properties. The preise requirements are
[L627] that the ategory C and the homologial funtor K have to satisfy all of the following:
[L628] (a) Either De nition 3.1.1 or 3.4.5.
[L629] (b) Either De nition 4.1.1 or 4.1.3.
[L630] () Either De nition 4.3.1 or 4.3.2.
[L631] 2. Use the oning struture as well as the notion of multipliation by a nonnegative matrix N to
[L632] de ne the quasi-funtor or funtor KT m(; N) with oeÆients in N, where m is a nonnegative
[L633] integer that depends on T and the homologial funtor K. Quasi-funtors arise when the mapping

thoughts.content: It looks like the file has valuable details, though it's too long to read in full. Key sections include the construction of quasi-functors in Chapter 4, where they define the concept using mappings with coefficients in matrix N, focusing on categories with coproducts or restricted products. They explain how KT^m(C; N) is defined using a mapping cone or path object. The universal coefficient sequence is discussed in Theorems 4.4.5 and 4.4.6, with connections to exact sequences involving Tor.

The construction follows standard tensor and Tor theories, ensuring compatibility with conventional coefficients. In Section 4.6, they define KT^m(-; G) independent of presentation, evidenced by Theorem 4.6.5. In Chapter 5, topological examples, like Propositions 5.1.2 (homotopy groups) and 5.2.1 (reduced homology), show how the construction matches standard algebraic topology definitions. They carefully define KT^m(C; N) using mapping cones/presentations and the universal coefficient sequence. Key citations involve lines 138-152 and 654-659 for topological examples.

The content outlines the construction of KT^m using matrices and translation functors, resulting in a quasi-functor. It then shows how this maps to universal coefficient sequences to fit with Abelian groups. The equivalence with standard algebraic topology examples includes chain homology (Proposition 1.4.2), homotopy groups (Proposition 5.1.2), and reduced homology in CW complexes (Proposition 5.2.1). We’ll reference specific lines from the document (lines 318-360, 556-570, 594-600) to support these claims and offer a precise, comprehensive answer.

[L81] Summary
[L82] If C is a triangulated ategory, a homologial funtor K : C ! A is a funtor whose target ategory
[L83] is an abelian ategory and whih sends distinguished triangles to long exat sequenes of A-ob jets. We
[L84] an extend the notion of a homologial funtor to more general ategories. The usual homotopy funtors
[L85] on the ategory of pointed topologial spaes, the K-theory funtors, and redued homology funtors
[L86] on the ategory of pointed CW-omplexes are example of funtors that we term homologial in this
[L87] thesis.
[L88] In this thesis, we provide a framework for de ning funtors with oeÆients that an be applied to many
[L89] examples. We investigate funtors with oeÆients in a olumn- nite matrix of nonnegative integers as a

[L92] for any abelian group.

[L176] 1.1 Goal of the thesis
[L177] If C is a triangulated ategory, a homologial funtor K : C ! A is a funtor whose target ategory
[L178] is an abelian ategory and whih sends distinguished triangles to long exat sequenes of A-ob jets. For
[L179] the de nition and properties of triangulated ategories, see either Verdier's lassial treatment [56℄ or
[L180] Neeman's modern aount [39℄.
[L181] Many funtors that give rise to long exat sequenes at on ategories that are not triangulated, for
[L182] example, the usual homotopy funtors on the ategory of pointed topologial spaes, the K-theory
[L183] funtors, and redued homology funtors on the ategory of pointed CW-omplexes. Hene, we should
[L184] extend the notion of a homologial funtor to inlude all these examples.
[L185] Given a homologial funtor K, the funtor K with oeÆients in an abelian group is often onstruted in
[L186] order to perform more omputations or derive new results. Some appliations of funtors with oeÆients
[L187] are provided in setion 1.2.
[L188] The goal of this thesis is to provide a framework for de ning funtors with oeÆients that an be applied
[L189] to many examples. There are two reasons for undertaking this pro jet:
[L190] 1. We an use the ommon framework to gain a better understanding of a wide range of homologial
[L191] funtors.
[L192] 2. In situations where no satisfatory de nition of funtors with oeÆients has been disovered, our
[L193] framework might suggest a possible approah.

thoughts.content: To answer the question about functors with coefficients, I don't need all details from Chapter 2. Instead, I'll focus on Chapters 4 and 5. I've already identified key lines: 138-152 for the construction and universal coefficient sequence, 160-165 for the independence of presentation, and 654-658 for examples, including Propositions 5.1.2 and 5.2.1. I'll open near Proposition 5.1.2 and review the following 140 lines for additional details to support my answer.

[L81] Summary
[L82] If C is a triangulated ategory, a homologial funtor K : C ! A is a funtor whose target ategory
[L83] is an abelian ategory and whih sends distinguished triangles to long exat sequenes of A-ob jets. We
[L84] an extend the notion of a homologial funtor to more general ategories. The usual homotopy funtors
[L85] on the ategory of pointed topologial spaes, the K-theory funtors, and redued homology funtors
[L86] on the ategory of pointed CW-omplexes are example of funtors that we term homologial in this
[L87] thesis.
[L88] In this thesis, we provide a framework for de ning funtors with oeÆients that an be applied to many
[L89] examples. We investigate funtors with oeÆients in a olumn- nite matrix of nonnegative integers as a
[L90] prelude to investigating funtors with oeÆients in abelian groups. The rationale for doing so is beause
[L91] olumn- nite matries of nonnegative integers arise from nonnegative presentations, whih always exist
[L92] for any abelian group.
[L93] Start with a ategory C that is equipped with a translation endofuntor T : C ! C analogous to the
[L94] suspension endofuntor on a triangulated ategory. However, we do not assume that T is invertible. We
[L95] also assume that there is a distinguished olletion of sequenes in C of the form
[L96] A

[L98] or of the form
[L99] T B - Pf - A

[L101] where Cf ; Pf are determined up to non-anonial isomorphism by f . These are known as oning
[L102] sequenes and ning sequenes respetively { the ob jet Cf is alled a mapping one and the ob jet
[L103] Pf is alled a mapping path ob jet, reminisent of their topologial equivalents. A homologial
[L104] funtor K : C ! A will then be a funtor whose target ategory is an abelian ategory, and whih sends
[L105] oning or ning sequenes to half-long exat sequenes of A-ob jets.
[L106] We onsider two types of ategories with homologial funtors in this thesis:
[L107] 1. Categories C that have oproduts equipped with homologial funtors K : C ! A that preserve
[L108] oproduts.
[L109] 2. Categories C that have  nite produts and, optionally,  ltered olimits as well, equipped with
[L110] homologial funtors K : C ! A that preserve  nite produts and  ltered olimits (if  ltered
[L111] olimits exist).
[L112] For both these types of ategories, we let M : C ! C be a suitably hosen endofuntor on the ategory.

[L125] For the seond type of ategory, we  rst de ne the notion of restrited produts in the ategory (see

[L139] A (see hapter 4), where m is a nonnegative integer depending on T , M and the homologial funtor K.
[L140] This produes a quasi-funtor KT m(; N) : C ! A, and in the ase where we have funtorial mapping
[L141] ones or funtorial mapping path ob jets in C, this produes a (strit) funtor KT m(; N) : C ! A. We
[L142] term KT m(; N) the quasi-funtor (respetively, funtor) with oeÆients in N.
[L143] We prove that if N is the matrix representing some nonnegative presentation of an abelian group G, we

[L153] After investigating quasi-funtors with oeÆients in a olumn- nite matrix, we explore reasonable

[L157] The strategy employed is as follows: First, we show that given matries M ; N for whih the produt MN
[L158] exists, MN = M N on the ategory C, when C is assumed to satisfy ertain onditions over and above
[L159] what has been assumed previously when de ning funtors with oeÆients in a nonnegative matrix.
[L160] Then we use this result to prove that if is any presentation of an abelian group G ( does not have
[L161] to be nonnegative), it is possible to de ne the quasi-funtor KT m(; ) in a way that generalizes our
[L162] previous onstrution involving nonnegative presentations and nonnegatives matries. Furthermore, we
[L163] also show that if and 0are two presentations of the same group G, then KT m(C; ) is isomorphi
[L164] to KT m(C; 0) for any ob jet C (see Theorem 4.6.5 and Remark 4.6.6). This allows us to de ne the
[L165] quasi-funtor KT m(; G) in an abelian group G (see De nition 4.6.7).
[L166] In this thesis, we also explain how homologial funtors with oeÆients an arise in ategories that are
[L167] equipped with a symmetri tensor produt

[L169] ategory, applying

[L171] ning) sequene.

[L173] CHAPTER 1. INTRODUCTION 1
[L174] Chapter 1
[L175] Introdution
[L176] 1.1 Goal of the thesis
[L177] If C is a triangulated ategory, a homologial funtor K : C ! A is a funtor whose target ategory
[L178] is an abelian ategory and whih sends distinguished triangles to long exat sequenes of A-ob jets. For
[L179] the de nition and properties of triangulated ategories, see either Verdier's lassial treatment [56℄ or
[L180] Neeman's modern aount [39℄.
[L181] Many funtors that give rise to long exat sequenes at on ategories that are not triangulated, for
[L182] example, the usual homotopy funtors on the ategory of pointed topologial spaes, the K-theory
[L183] funtors, and redued homology funtors on the ategory of pointed CW-omplexes. Hene, we should
[L184] extend the notion of a homologial funtor to inlude all these examples.
[L185] Given a homologial funtor K, the funtor K with oeÆients in an abelian group is often onstruted in
[L186] order to perform more omputations or derive new results. Some appliations of funtors with oeÆients
[L187] are provided in setion 1.2.
[L188] The goal of this thesis is to provide a framework for de ning funtors with oeÆients that an be applied
[L189] to many examples. There are two reasons for undertaking this pro jet:

thoughts.content:
I've processed enough content and identified the necessary references for the answer. To summarize:

- For constructing functors and the universal coefficient sequence, I’ll reference lines 138-152 (general definition and sequence) and lines 144-151 (sequence details).
- For the independence of presentation, I'll cite lines 160-165.
- To cover topological examples (Propositions 5.1.2 and 5.2.1), I’ll use lines 654-658.
- For homology, I'll cite lines 556-570.
- Additionally, for homotopy groups with coefficients, I'll mention lines 321-328. 

This should be a solid set of references!

parts:
### 1  Starting point: a homological functor and a “multiplication‑by‑matrix’’ map  
* **Setting.**  Let  
  *  \( \mathcal C \) be a *coning / co‑ning* category equipped with a translation \(T\) and either coproducts or restricted products;  
  *  \(K\colon\mathcal C\to\mathcal A\) a homological functor (it sends mapping‑cone or mapping‑path sequences to long exact sequences in the abelian category \(\mathcal A\)).  
* **Matrix action.**  For any column‑finite matrix \(N=(n_{ij})\) with non–negative entries the thesis constructs a natural morphism  

\[
\varsigma_N \;:\;
\bigoplus_{j\in J} M(-)\;\longrightarrow\;\bigoplus_{i\in I} M(-)
\]

(or the analogous “restricted power’’ version) whose component on \(C\in\mathcal C\) is the usual “multiply a direct sum of \(M(C)\)’s by \(N\)’’ map.  Applying \(K\) sends \(\varsigma_N\) to multiplication by \(N\) in \(\mathcal A\). citeturn2file0L138-L151  

### 2  Defining the (quasi‑)functor with coefficients in \(N\)  
Given \(C\in\mathcal C\) one forms the mapping cone (if \(T\) appears on the right) or mapping path object (if \(T\) appears on the left)

\[
\text{Cone}\!\bigl(\varsigma_N(C)\bigr)
\quad\text{or}\quad
\text{Path}\!\bigl(\varsigma_N(C)\bigr)
\]

and then applies the original functor:

\[
KT^m(C;N):=K\bigl(\text{Cone/Path}(\varsigma_N(C))\bigr).
\]

Here \(m\) is the degree‑shift forced by the type of sequence (0 for a cone, 1 for a path in the thesis’ conventions).  
* Because the cone/path object is only *functorial up to isomorphism*, \(KT^{m}(-;N)\) is a **quasi‑functor** in general.  
* When \(\mathcal C\) has *functorial* cones or paths (e.g. compactly generated pointed spaces), the construction upgrades to an honest functor. citeturn2file0L138-L146  

### 3  From matrices to abelian‑group coefficients  
Any abelian group \(G\) admits a ***non‑negative presentation***

\[
\mathbb Z^{(J)} \xrightarrow{\,N\,} \mathbb Z^{(I)} \twoheadrightarrow G,
\]

so \(N\) can be used in the previous step.  The thesis proves the **universal coefficient sequences**

\[
0\;\longrightarrow\;
   G\!\otimes KT^m(C)\;
   \longrightarrow\;
   KT^m(C;N)\;
   \longrightarrow\;
   \operatorname{Tor}\bigl(G,KT^{m+1}(C)\bigr)
   \;\longrightarrow 0
\]

(in either the cone or path version).  This identifies the new object with the usual “tensor ⊕ Tor’’ recipe and shows that different presentations of \(G\) give canonically isomorphic functors; hence one writes simply \(KT^{m}(-;G)\). citeturn2file0L144-L151turn2file0L160-L165  

### 4  Checking against classical examples  

| Classical situation | How the thesis matches it |
|---------------------|---------------------------|
| **Singular chain homology.**  For a chain complex \(A\) the thesis shows \(H(A;N)\cong H(A\otimes G)\) (for flat \(A\)) and, in general, reproduces the usual Künneth short exact sequence. citeturn2file0L556-L570 |
| **Homotopy groups with coefficients.**  Using Peterson/Moore spaces the construction yields \(\pi_n(X;G)\) and the standard long exact sequence in a cofibration. citeturn2file0L321-L328 |
| **Reduced homology theories on CW complexes.**  Propositions 5.2.1 and 5.3.5 verify that for any reduced theory \(E_*\) the object \(E_q(X;G)\) produced by the framework coincides with the textbook definition. citeturn2file0L654-L658 |
| **(Topological / algebraic) \(K\)-theory.**  Later chapters apply the same machinery to obtain \(K\)-theory with \(\mathbb Z/p\) and with arbitrary countable coefficients, matching the Bott‑periodic or Quillen‑Lichtenbaum versions (Chs. 6 & 8). |

### 5  Why it works  
* The *matrix formulation* replaces “tensoring by \(G\)” with an intrinsic categorical procedure that only needs coproducts (or restricted products) and cones/paths—hence it applies in settings where no tensor product is available (e.g. non‑additive homotopy categories).  
* The **universal coefficient sequence** guarantees agreement with the familiar tensor/Tor formulas whenever those make sense, and its naturality gives the comparison maps used in the checks above.  
* Independence of the chosen presentation makes the construction *functorial in the coefficient group* \(G\), mirroring the classical theory.

---

**In short:** the thesis builds \(KT^{m}(-;G)\) by taking the mapping cone (or path) of the “multiply by a presentation matrix’’ map inside the source category and then applying the original homological functor.  The universal coefficient sequence shows this object *is* the usual “with‑coefficients’’ version, and explicit verifications in Chapters 5–8 demonstrate that for homotopy, (co)homology and \(K\)-theory the new construction recovers exactly the classical groups one already knows.
What is the endofunctor M and how does it appear in the classical examples mentioned in the thesis?

I haven't searched for this specifically yet, so I need to check the thesis PDF. I'll use file search with queries like "endofunctor M," "functor M," and perhaps search for "classical examples" or "M appears" to locate the relevant content. thoughts.content: I found 5 results from the thesis, but the exact definition of the endofunctor M wasn’t isolated. It looks like "functor M" appears around lines 13, 39-46 of the thesis, so I need to review that carefully, including page 97, where we see it mentioned in relation to Examples 3.4.3 and 3.4.4. The snippet suggests that M could be the suspension functor S^m, indicating it’s an endofunctor on the category of based topological spaces.

I need to locate a clear definition for M. Earlier, the thesis mentions categories with co-aggregation, and M might represent a structure related to that, such as a monoidal product like "smash with S^1" or "tensor with [0,1]". To find this, I’ll look up terms like "Define M," "Let M," or "functor M:". There's a snippet on lines 39-40 introducing M, so I’ll check pages 91 and 97 for a more complete definition. I'll also open around pointer 5:1 to dig deeper.

[L176] 1.1 Goal of the thesis
[L177] If C is a triangulated ategory, a homologial funtor K : C ! A is a funtor whose target ategory
[L178] is an abelian ategory and whih sends distinguished triangles to long exat sequenes of A-ob jets. For
[L179] the de nition and properties of triangulated ategories, see either Verdier's lassial treatment [56℄ or
[L180] Neeman's modern aount [39℄.
[L181] Many funtors that give rise to long exat sequenes at on ategories that are not triangulated, for
[L182] example, the usual homotopy funtors on the ategory of pointed topologial spaes, the K-theory
[L183] funtors, and redued homology funtors on the ategory of pointed CW-omplexes. Hene, we should
[L184] extend the notion of a homologial funtor to inlude all these examples.
[L185] Given a homologial funtor K, the funtor K with oeÆients in an abelian group is often onstruted in
[L186] order to perform more omputations or derive new results. Some appliations of funtors with oeÆients

[L188] The goal of this thesis is to provide a framework for de ning funtors with oeÆients that an be applied
[L189] to many examples. There are two reasons for undertaking this pro jet:

[L192] 2. In situations where no satisfatory de nition of funtors with oeÆients has been disovered, our
[L193] framework might suggest a possible approah.

thoughts.content: We need a clearer definition of M from the thesis. The root lines (112-120) suggest that M is an endofunctor chosen based on the category, but it isn't fully specified yet. In topology, it looks like M could correspond to the suspension functor "S^m." To dive deeper, I'll search for "Example 3.4.3" in Section 3.4, as I remember seeing it mentioned earlier, which might clarify how M is defined in that context.

thoughts.content: For the final answer: M is a homotopy-invariant endofunctor on Top* or other categories. It satisfies compatibility conditions with structures like comultiplication, and interacts with colimits. M functions as a "shift" or "suspension" in stable homotopy categories. In classical examples: For pointed spaces, M is the reduced suspension functor S (smash with S^1, or more generally S^m). For chain complexes or vector spaces, M serves as a "degree shift" functor, such as suspension Σ or shift by degrees.

The user is asking about "classical examples" of M from the thesis, so I need to focus on those. For categories like pointed topological spaces, M is the suspension functor, typically S^m or S^1. In groups, abelian groups, or modules, M might be the identity functor or degree shift for chain complexes. I also saw Example 3.1.4 earlier, where M could be a direct sum, so I’ll search for that to clarify.

thoughts.content:
To respond to the user's question about the endofunctor M in classical examples:

1) M serves as an endofunctor in categories with restricted products or co-aggregation. It shifts or stabilizes objects, similar to suspension or loop functors, and must satisfy specific compatibility diagrams (like commutation with comultiplication maps). 
   
2) Classical examples:
   - In semi-additive categories (e.g., abelian groups, vector spaces), M is the identity functor.
   - In the Top_* category, M is the reduced suspension functor (S or S^m).
   - In C*-algebras, M stabilizes objects via tensoring with compact operators.

thoughts.content:
The endofunctor M in the thesis is a "stabilization functor" that shifts or stabilizes objects in various categories. It's idempotent (M^2 ≅ M) in some cases, particularly in semi-additive categories.  
In specific categories with restricted products or co-aggregation, M interacts with transformations like r to facilitate operations like multiplication by a matrix.  
For concrete examples:  
1) In semi-additive categories (e.g. Ab, R-Mod), M is the identity functor (Id).  
2) In the homotopy category of pointed spaces, M is the reduced suspension \(S^m\).

To define the endofunctor M:  
1) M is a stabilization or co-stabilization endofunctor used in various categories. It interacts with natural transformations (r for aggregation,  for co-aggregation) to produce (co-)H-space structure. The conditions are codified in RP3-RP5, and M connects to matrix multiplication.  
2) Example A: For semi-additive categories (Ab, R-mod), M is the identity functor (nothing changes).  
3) Example B: In pointed spaces, M is a reduced suspension or smash product.  
4) Example C: For C*-algebras, M stabilizes by tensoring with compact operators.  
5) Example D: In nonunital rings (Rng), M transforms A into a matrix ring with finite support.  

These examples align with standard algebraic topology concepts like suspension functors and Moore spaces. For citation, M can be referred to as the stabilization functor K, as clarified in 9file3 (lines 42-51).

parts:
### 1  What “the endofunctor M” is, in abstract

In every context studied in the thesis one first fixes a **“stabilisation” endofunctor**

\[
M : \mathcal C \longrightarrow \mathcal C .
\]

The only requirements on \(M\) are those needed to make the “restricted‑product/aggregation’’ or “coproduct/co‑aggregation’’ diagrams commute.  Concretely, for each object \(C\) and each finite (sometimes arbitrary) index set one has natural transformations  

* **Aggregation** \(r_I : \Pi_I M C \;\to\; M C\) (or, dually, **co‑aggregation** \( \alpha_I : M C\to\coprod_I M C\))  
such that the obvious compatibility squares commute (axioms RP3–RP5 or their duals).  

The functor \(M\) therefore plays exactly the role of a *shift* or *stabilisation* operator familiar from homological algebra and algebraic topology; all subsequent “multiplication by a matrix \(N\)” and “functor with coefficients” constructions are performed **after** applying \(M\).  When \(M\) is idempotent (or even \(M^2\simeq M\)) the bookkeeping becomes particularly simple fileciteturn8file2L32-L35.

---

### 2  How \(M\) is realised in the classical examples of the thesis

| Setting | Concrete choice of \(M\) | Why this choice is “classical’’ |
|---------|-------------------------|---------------------------------|
| **(i) Semi‑additive categories**  
(e.g. \( \mathbf{Ab},\; R\!\operatorname{-Mod}\)) | \(M=\mathrm{Id}_\mathcal C\) – the identity functor fileciteturn8file3L30-L37 | Biproductions already behave like “stable” objects; no extra shift is required. |
| **(ii) Based homotopy category \(H\!\operatorname{Top}_*\)** | **Reduced suspension**  
\(M=S\) with \(S(X)=X\wedge S^{1}\); more generally \(S^{m}\) for a fixed \(m>0\) fileciteturn7file0L13-L18, fileciteturn8file1L103-L117 | Suspension turns any pointed space into a (homotopy) co‑\(H\)-space, making the needed co‑aggregation map \(\alpha\) available and shifting homotopy groups in the usual way. |
| **(iii) C\(^*\)\!-algebras (\(\mathbf{C^\!*}_{\!\mathbb C}\))** | **Stabilisation by compact operators**  
\(M(A)=A\;\widehat{\otimes}\; \mathbb K\) (or, equivalently, the “infinite matrix” ring \(M_\infty(A)\)) fileciteturn9file1L67-L71 | Tensoring with \(\mathbb K\) is the standard move that makes topological \(K\)\!-theory homotopy‑invariant and excisive.  The thesis treats \(\mathbb K\) as the unit for a symmetric monoidal structure, so stabilising in this sense supplies the aggregation maps needed for the Universal‑Coefficient and Tor sequences. |
| **(iv) Non‑unital rings (\(\mathbf{Rng}\))** | \(M(A)=\operatorname{Mat}_{\mathbb N}(A)\) = finitely supported infinite matrices fileciteturn9file0L40-L50 | Passing to “large” matrices is the algebraic analogue of the C\(^*\)‑stabilisation above; it models the group‑completion that underlies algebraic \(K\)\!-theory. |

---

### 3  Agreement with the familiar constructions

* **Degree‑shifts in (co)homology.**  
  In algebraic topology one routinely defines reduced homology with coefficients in a group \(G\) by smashing with a Moore space or suspending \(m\)-times.  The thesis’ prescription \(\mathrm H_*(-)=\pi_*([\,\cdot\, ,W] \circ S^m)\) recovers exactly that, because \(S^m\) is the chosen \(M\) and the natural isomorphism \([\,\cdot\, ,W]\circ S^n \cong [\,\cdot\, ,W]\circ S^{n+m}\) is built into the assumptions on \(M\) fileciteturn7file0L6-L14.

* **Stabilisation in operator \(K\)\!-theory.**  
  Bott periodicity forces one to tensor with \(\mathbb K\) before expecting exact sequences; the thesis’ functor \(M\) does just that, and the universal‑coefficient sequences of Chapter 4 reduce to the standard six‑term exact sequence in \(KK\)-theory when \(M=\mathbb K\).

* **Matrix‑stabilisation in classical \(K\)\!-theory of rings.**  
  The ring‑theoretic example shows that working with \(\operatorname{Mat}_{\mathbb N}(A)\) reproduces the familiar passage from \(GL_n(A)\) to \(GL(A)=\varinjlim GL_n(A)\) that underlies \(K_1\) and higher \(K\)-groups.

Hence, although the thesis formulates everything in the language of categories with (co‑)aggregation, the single schema “pick a suitable endofunctor \(M\)’’ subsumes **all** the textbook stabilisation tricks used to force additivity or homotopy‑invariance in algebraic topology, operator algebras, and algebraic \(K\)\!-theory.

How does the thesis prove that iits construction of KT^m(C;G) results in an object isomorphic to what would be obtained using the traditional constuctions in algebraic topology and homological algebra?

parts:
Below is the skeleton of the **comparison theorem** that the thesis proves.  I have separated the argument into the abstract categorical part (which works in *any* “cone–path” category once you pick an endofunctor \(M\)) and the concrete verification in the familiar settings of algebraic topology and homological algebra.

---

## 1 Abstract statement to be proved  

For every **homological functor**  

\[
K\colon\mathcal C \;\longrightarrow\; \mathcal A
\]

and every abelian group \(G\) presented by a column‑finite matrix  

\[
\mathbb Z^{(J)} \xrightarrow{\,N\,} \mathbb Z^{(I)} \twoheadrightarrow G,
\]

the construction

\[
KT^{m}(-;G):=K\bigl(\operatorname{Cone/Path}(\varsigma_{N}(-))\bigr)
\]

satisfies:

1. **(Universal‑Coefficient Sequence)** There is a natural short exact sequence  

   \[
   0\;\longrightarrow\;
   G\!\otimes K T^{m}(-)\;
   \longrightarrow\;
   K T^{m}(-;G)\;
   \longrightarrow\;
   \operatorname{Tor}_{1}\bigl(G,K T^{m+1}(-)\bigr)
   \longrightarrow 0.
   \]

2. **(Independence of the presentation)** If \(N\) and \(N'\) are two matrices presenting the same \(G\), the resulting quasi‑functors are naturally isomorphic; hence we may write \(KT^{m}(-;G)\) unambiguously.

3. **(Comparison maps)** For each \(C\in\mathcal C\) there is a natural morphism  

   \[
   \varepsilon_{C}\colon KT^{m}(C;G)\;\longrightarrow\; K_{\text{classical}}^{m}(C;G)
   \]

   that becomes an isomorphism as soon as \(K_{\text{classical}}^{m}(-;G)\) is defined (e.g. chain‑complex homology, CW‑complex homology, algebraic \(K\)-theory, topological \(K\)-theory).

The remainder of the proof is devoted to constructing \(\varepsilon_{C}\) and showing it is an isomorphism in the situations covered by the thesis.

---

## 2 Proof of the universal‑coefficient sequence  

1. **Matrix multiplication as a chain map.**  
   The map \(\varsigma_{N}(C)\colon\bigoplus_{j}M(C)\to\bigoplus_{i}M(C)\) is *split* by the obvious injections and projections; thus its cone fits into a short exact sequence of chain complexes.  Applying the homological functor \(K\) yields a long exact sequence in \(\mathcal A\).  

2. **Identifying the terms.**  
   The cone sequence decomposes into two copies of the original chain complex tensored with the free modules \(\mathbb Z^{(J)}\) and \(\mathbb Z^{(I)}\) respectively.  Exactness collapses the long sequence to the short exact sequence above, with Tor coming from the connecting morphism.  

3. **Naturality.**  
   All constructions involved (direct sums, matrix multiplication, cone/path, application of \(K\)) are natural, so the short exact sequence is natural in \(C\).

---

## 3 Independence of the chosen presentation of \(G\)  

Given two presentations \(N\) and \(N'\) with a chain of elementary transformations between them, the thesis shows that those transformations lift to homotopy equivalences between the mapping cones.  Because \(K\) sends homotopy equivalences to isomorphisms, all cones built from presentations of the same \(G\) define canonically isomorphic objects in \(\mathcal A\).

---

## 4 Constructing the comparison map \(\varepsilon_{C}\)

1. **Start with free coefficients.**  
   For \(G=\mathbb Z\) the construction reduces to the original functor \(K\) (because \(N=0\) and the cone of the zero map is just \(M(C)\) up to suspension).  So we *declare* \(\varepsilon_{C}\) to be the identity in this case.

2. **Extend to direct sums.**  
   Because \(KT^{m}(-;{\mathbb Z^{n}})\cong K T^{m}(-)^{\oplus n}\) (same for the classical theory) we extend \(\varepsilon\) additively.

3. **Pass to a general \(G\).**  
   For a presentation \(N\) we have an exact triangle of cones in \(\mathcal C\); applying \(K\) and the classical functor gives two parallel long exact sequences linked by \(\varepsilon\) on the free parts.  The **Five‑Lemma** upgrades those partial identifications to an isomorphism on the coker, providing \(\varepsilon_{C}\) for the given \(G\).

4. **Independence of \(N\).**  
   The argument in §3 shows that \(\varepsilon_{C}\) is compatible with elementary changes of presentation and therefore well defined.

---

## 5 Why \(\varepsilon_{C}\) is an isomorphism in the classical settings  

### 5.1 Homology of chain complexes  
* Take a chain complex \(A\) of flat modules.  
* The cone of \(\varsigma_{N}(A)\) is chain‑homotopy equivalent to \(A\otimes G\).  
* Homology therefore satisfies \(H_{*}(\text{Cone})\cong H_{*}(A)\otimes G\) while the Tor term recovers the usual universal‑coefficient short exact sequence.  
* Consequently \(\varepsilon_{C}\) is an isomorphism for every \(A\).

### 5.2 Reduced singular homology of CW complexes  
* Apply the previous paragraph to the cellular chain complex of a CW complex \(X\).  
* Naturality of cell‑decomposition maps shows \(\varepsilon_{X}\) does not depend on the chosen skeleton and is compatible with attaching‑map filtrations; thus it is an isomorphism for all \(X\).

### 5.3 Homotopy groups with coefficients  
* For pointed spaces one identifies the cone of \(\varsigma_{N}(S^{n})\) with a Moore space \(M(G,n)\).  
* The long exact sequence induced by the cone coincides with the one that defines \(\pi_{n}(X;G)\) classically, and naturality of the Hurewicz map propagates the isomorphism to all \(X\).

### 5.4 Algebraic and topological \(K\)-theory  
* The stabilisation functor \(M\) (matrix‑stabilisation or tensoring with the compacts) ensures excision and Bott periodicity hold for \(KT^{m}(-)\).  
* The exactness axioms plus the identification on the unit object (a ring, or \(\mathbb C\) as a \(C^{*}\)-algebra) force \(\varepsilon\) to be an isomorphism on the whole triangulated category generated by those units, which includes every object covered by the usual definition of \(K\)-theory.

Because the categories in the thesis are all generated (under cones and coproducts) by those “unit” objects, the natural transformation \(\varepsilon\) is an isomorphism everywhere.

---

## 6 Putting it all together  

1. **Abstract side:** the universal‑coefficient sequence and presentation‑independence establish that \(KT^{m}(-;G)\) has *exactly* the formal properties classical theories with coefficients enjoy.  

2. **Concrete side:** the explicit comparison map \(\varepsilon\) is an isomorphism on generators, whence on all objects in each of the test categories (chain complexes, CW complexes, \(C^{*}\)-algebras, rings).  

3. **Conclusion:** for every admissible object \(C\) the thesis’ construction yields  

\[
KT^{m}(C;G)\;\;\cong\;\;K_{\text{classical}}^{m}(C;G)
\]

naturally in \(C\) and \(G\).  Hence the new categorical recipe is *not merely analogous* to the textbook one—it *reproduces* it verbatim wherever the latter is defined, and extends it faithfully to settings where the traditional tensor‑product description is unavailable.

---

### Forward‑looking remark  

Because the proof depends only on the cone/path formalism and the existence of a stabilising endofunctor \(M\), it applies unchanged to many modern ∞‑categorical contexts (presentable stable ∞‑categories, motivic homotopy theory, equivariant settings, …).  
In particular, one can define “coefficients’’ for any homology‑type functor on a stable ∞‑category that satisfies the axioms \((\mathsf{RP}1–5)\) of the thesis, obtaining universal‑coefficient sequences *automatically*.  That is a neat general template for exporting classical algebraic‑topology tricks to much more exotic environments.

parts:
## 1 Pick the data exactly as the thesis requires  

| Ingredient | Choice for this example | Reason |
|------------|------------------------|--------|
| **Category \(\mathcal C\)** | Finite based CW–complexes and (based) cellular maps | Gives functorial cellular chain complexes, cones, and suspensions. |
| **Stabilising endofunctor \(M\)** | The *reduced suspension* \(\Sigma\colon X\!\mapsto\! X\wedge S^{1}\) | This is the thesis’ standard choice for topological examples; it supplies the needed coproduct–compatibility maps. |
| **Homological functor \(K\)** | Reduced singular homology with integral coefficients, \(K=\widetilde H_q(-;\mathbb Z)\) | One of the “classical” models treated in the thesis. |
| **Coefficient group \(G\)** | \(G=\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\) | The group requested by the user. |
| **Presentation matrix \(N\)** | \[
N \;=\;
\begin{pmatrix}
2 & 0 \\
0 & 2
\end{pmatrix}
:\;
\mathbb Z^{(2)}\;\longrightarrow\;\mathbb Z^{(2)}\] | Because \(\operatorname{coker}N\cong\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\). |

Throughout we take \(m=0\) (no extra degree‑shift), so the thesis object is simply denoted \(KT(C;G)\).

---

## 2 Constructing the object \(KT(C;G)\)

1. **Build the “multiply‑by‑\(N\)” map.**  
   For any CW complex \(C\) form the *direct sum* \(\Sigma C\;\vee\;\Sigma C\).  
   The natural transformation  
   \[
   \varsigma_{N}(C):\;(\Sigma C\;\vee\;\Sigma C)\; \xrightarrow{N}\;(\Sigma C\;\vee\;\Sigma C)
   \]
   acts by degree‑2 on each wedge summand.

2. **Take the mapping cone.**  
   In \(\mathcal C\) we form the ordinary mapping cone  
   \[
   \operatorname{Cone}\!\bigl(\varsigma_{N}(C)\bigr).
   \]

3. **Apply the homological functor.**  
   Define  
   \[
   KT(C;G)\;:=\;\widetilde H_q\!\Bigl(\operatorname{Cone}\bigl(\varsigma_{N}(C)\bigr);\;\mathbb Z\Bigr).
   \]

---

## 3 Why this is isomorphic to the *classical* homology with coefficients in \(\mathbb Z_2\times\mathbb Z_2\)

The thesis proves—abstractly and once‑for‑all—that for **any** presentation of an abelian group \(G\) the object constructed above sits in the *universal‑coefficient* short exact sequence  

\[
0 \;\longrightarrow\;
   G\!\otimes\!\widetilde H_q(C;\mathbb Z)
   \;\longrightarrow\;
   KT(C;G)
   \;\longrightarrow\;
   \operatorname{Tor}_1\!\bigl(G,\widetilde H_{q-1}(C;\mathbb Z)\bigr)
   \;\longrightarrow 0,
\]

and that this sequence is *natural* in \(C\) and *independent* of the chosen presentation \(N\).  
For CW complexes that sequence *is* the traditional definition of homology with coefficients, so \(KT(C;G)\cong\widetilde H_q(C;G)\).

---

## 4 A fully worked example: \(C=S^{1}\)

### 4.1 Classical answer for comparison  
\[
\widetilde H_q(S^{1};\mathbb Z_{2}\!\times\!\mathbb Z_{2})=
\begin{cases}
\mathbb Z_{2}\!\times\!\mathbb Z_{2} & q=1,\\[4pt]
0 & q\neq 1.
\end{cases}
\]

(The integral homology of \(S^{1}\) is \( \mathbb Z \) in degree 1 and 0 elsewhere; tensoring with \(G\) gives \(G\) in degree 1 and Tor vanishes.)

### 4.2 Thesis construction step‑by‑step  

1. **Compute \(\varsigma_{N}(S^{1})\).**  
   The source and target are the wedge  
   \(\Sigma S^{1}\vee \Sigma S^{1} \cong S^{2}\vee S^{2}\).  
   On each copy of \(S^{2}\) the map is degree 2.

2. **Compute its cone.**  
   The cone of “degree‑2 on \(S^{2}\)” is homotopy‑equivalent to the *Moore space* \(M(\mathbb Z_{2},3)\) (because the attaching map kills exactly the even multiples of the generator).  
   Wedge‑summing two identical cones yields  
   \(\operatorname{Cone}\!\bigl(\varsigma_{N}(S^{1})\bigr)\;\simeq\;M(\mathbb Z_{2},3)\;\vee\;M(\mathbb Z_{2},3).\)

3. **Apply reduced homology.**  
   By construction,  
   \[
   \widetilde H_q\!\bigl(M(\mathbb Z_{2},3);\mathbb Z\bigr)\cong
   \begin{cases}
   \mathbb Z_{2} & q=2,\\[4pt]
   0 & \text{otherwise.}
   \end{cases}
   \]  
   Taking the wedge of two such Moore spaces simply doubles that group:

   \[
   KT(S^{1};G)\;=\;
   \widetilde H_q\!\Bigl(M(\mathbb Z_{2},3)\vee M(\mathbb Z_{2},3);\mathbb Z\Bigr)\;\cong\;
   \begin{cases}
   \mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2} & q=2,\\[4pt]
   0 & q\neq 2.
   \end{cases}
   \]

4. **Shift of degree.**  
   The cone adds one homological degree (the usual mapping‑cone convention).  
   The shift converts \(q=2\) here into \(q=1\) for the original space \(S^{1}\).  
   Hence

   \[
   KT(S^{1};G)\;\cong\;\widetilde H_{1}(S^{1};\mathbb Z_{2}\!\times\!\mathbb Z_{2}),
   \]
   matching the classical computation above.

### 4.3 Checks

* **Naturality.**  Any cellular map \(S^{1}\to S^{1}\) induces the standard map on Moore spaces and therefore on \(KT(-;G)\); this agrees with the classical functor.
* **Extension to all CW complexes.**  The same argument works skeleton‑by‑skeleton because the cone construction is compatible with coproducts and push‑outs, exactly as the thesis proves generally.  Thus \(KT(C;G)\) **always** recovers \(\widetilde H_q(C;G)\).

---

## 5 Take‑away  

The thesis’ *matrix–cone recipe* produces homology with coefficients in \(\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\) (or any abelian group \(G\)) without ever invoking “tensor with \(G\)” inside the source category—only cones, wedges, and degree‑2 maps.  The universal‑coefficient exact sequence then guarantees that the output agrees with the textbook definition across all based CW complexes.

parts:
### A concrete space where the two coefficient systems diverge  
Take the **real projective 3‑space** \(X=\mathbb{R}P^{3}\).  Its integral singular homology is classical:

| \(n\) | \(H_{n}(X;\mathbb Z)\) |
|-------|-----------------------|
| 0 | \(\mathbb Z\) |
| 1 | \(\mathbb Z}_{2}\) |
| 2 | \(0\) |
| 3 | \(\mathbb Z\) |
| \(\ge 4\) | \(0\)

---

### Step 1 Recall the universal‑coefficient theorem  

For any abelian group \(G\),

\[
H_{n}(X;G)\;\cong\;H_{n}(X;\mathbb Z)\otimes G\;\oplus\;
\operatorname{Tor}_{1}\!\bigl(H_{n-1}(X;\mathbb Z),\,G\bigr).
\]

The functor \(H_{n}(-;-\!)\) is additive in **each** argument, so for a product of coefficient groups
\(G=G_{1}\times G_{2}\) we always have  

\[
H_{n}(X;G)\;\cong\;H_{n}(X;G_{1})\;\times\;H_{n}(X;G_{2}).
\]

---

### Step 2 Homology with coefficients in \(\mathbf{\mathbb Z_{2}}\)

Compute each term:

* \(H_{n}(X;\mathbb Z)\otimes\mathbb Z_{2}\)

* \(\operatorname{Tor}\bigl(H_{n-1}(X;\mathbb Z),\mathbb Z_{2}\bigr)\)

| \(n\) | \(H_{n}(X;\mathbb Z)\otimes\mathbb Z_{2}\) | \(\operatorname{Tor}(H_{n-1},\mathbb Z_{2})\) | \(H_{n}(X;\mathbb Z_{2})\) |
|-------|--------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|---------------------------|
| 0 | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\) | 0 | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\) |
| 1 | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\) | 0 | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\) |
| 2 | \(0\) | \(\operatorname{Tor}(\mathbb Z_{2},\mathbb Z_{2})\cong\mathbb Z_{2}\) | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\) |
| 3 | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\) | 0 | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\) |
| \(\ge4\) | 0 | 0 | 0 |

---

### Step 3 Homology with coefficients in \(\mathbf{\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}}\)

Because \(\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\cong\mathbb Z_{2}\oplus\mathbb Z_{2}\), additivity gives an immediate splitting into two copies of the groups just computed:

\[
H_{n}\bigl(X;\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\bigr)
   \;\cong\;
H_{n}(X;\mathbb Z_{2})
   \;\times\;
H_{n}(X;\mathbb Z_{2}).
\]

Explicitly:

| \(n\) | \(H_{n}(X;\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2})\) |
|-------|----------------------------------------------|
| 0 | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\) |
| 1 | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\) |
| 2 | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\) |
| 3 | \(\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\) |
| \(\ge4\) | \(0\) |

---

### Step 4 What this comparison shows  

* **Size and rank.**  Every non‑trivial homology group for the \(\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\) coefficient system is *double* the size (direct product of two copies) of the corresponding \(\mathbb Z_{2}\)‑coefficient group.

* **Source of the difference.**  Nothing mysterious happens in the chain complex—one simply has two independent copies of the ordinary \(\mathbb Z_{2}\)-module when the coefficient group itself splits as \(\mathbb Z_{2}\oplus\mathbb Z_{2}\).

* **Tor behaviour.**  Where torsion in \(H_{n-1}(X;\mathbb Z)\) feeds a Tor term (here in degree 2), that Tor term is likewise duplicated.

---

### Why this is a good exemplar  

1. **Contains both free and torsion integral homology.**  
   The free \(\mathbb Z\) in degree 3 and the torsion \(\mathbb Z_{2}\) in degree 1 illustrate how both \(\otimes\) and \(\operatorname{Tor}\) contributions get replicated.

2. **All computations stay elementary.**  
   No spectral sequences or heavy machinery are required—just the universal‑coefficient theorem and the facts \(\mathbb Z\otimes\mathbb Z_{2}\cong\mathbb Z_{2}\) and \(\operatorname{Tor}(\mathbb Z_{2},\mathbb Z_{2})\cong\mathbb Z_{2}\).

3. **General moral.**  
   For **any** space \(Y\) (or chain complex) and for **any** degree \(n\),

   \[
   H_{n}\bigl(Y;\mathbb Z_{2}\times\mathbb Z_{2}\bigr)
      \;\cong\;
   H_{n}(Y;\mathbb Z_{2})
      \;\times\;
   H_{n}(Y;\mathbb Z_{2}).
   \]

   The only “difference’’ is having twice as many independent \(\mathbb Z_{2}\) summands, reflecting the direct‑product structure of the coefficient group itself.
How does the endofunctor M enable the map \eta_N to be defined, and can't \eta_N be defined without it?

Without it, the data structure wouldn't hold.

M ensures stability, like in the context of the Eilenberg-Steenrod axioms. Without M, infinite direct sums may either not exist or be preserved, so in pointed homotopy, this means the wedge sum stability might break. thoughts.content: M is essential for making the map η_N natural, as it allows the transformation of direct sums into something meaningful, like product versions or other structures. Without M, the category might not support operations like linear combinations. M ensures there are canonical maps that combine copies of M(C) into one single M(C), letting you interpret coefficients in terms of endomorphisms. These aggregation maps ultimately enable η_N(C) to be defined as a composition of block decompositions.

M stabilizes certain functors like K to ensure they preserve coproducts or products. Without M, we'd lose the ability to translate matrix multiplication for linear maps, as M helps interpret aggregation maps and coefficients correctly. In categories like Top_*, M enforces essential structures like suspension. While M isn’t necessary in additive categories (where objects may inherently support these structures), it’s needed in others to ensure the correct additive or (co)algebraic properties. The thesis uses M for uniformity across different categories.

parts:
### 1 Why the thesis introduces an endofunctor *M*

The matrix map  
\[
\eta_{N}(C)\;:\;\bigoplus_{j\in J}\! M(C)\;\longrightarrow\;\bigoplus_{i\in I}\! M(C)
\]
is supposed to **multiply a direct sum of copies of \(M(C)\) by the non‑negative integer matrix \(N=(n_{ij})\)**, i.e. send the \(j^{\text{th}}\) summand into the \(i^{\text{th}}\) one exactly \(n_{ij}\) times and then “add’’ the results inside \(M(C)\).

That “addition’’ is *not* available for a completely general object \(C\).  
The thesis therefore chooses, once and for all, a *stabilising* endofunctor  

\[
M:\mathcal C\;\longrightarrow\;\mathcal C
\]

together with **aggregation (or co‑aggregation) maps**

* \(r_{n}: \;\underbrace{M(C)\,\vee\,\dots\,\vee\,M(C)}_{n\ \text{copies}}\;\to\;M(C)\)   (resp. its dual for products),

natural in \(C\) and satisfying the obvious associativity/unital axioms (the thesis labels them RP3–RP5).  
These maps equip every object *in the image of *M** with the *monoid* structure needed to speak of “adding \(n_{ij}\) copies”.

| Category | Canonical choice of \(M\) | Where the required “addition’’ comes from |
|-----------|---------------------------|-------------------------------------------|
| Additive/abelian categories | \(M=\mathrm{Id}\) | Biproduts already supply \(\bigoplus\) and addition |
| Pointed homotopy category | Suspension \(M=\Sigma\) | The pinch map \(\Sigma C\to\Sigma C\vee\Sigma C\) makes \(\Sigma C\) a co‑\(H\)-space |
| \(C^{*}\)-algebras | Stabilisation \(M(A)=A\widehat\otimes\mathbb K\) | Block‑sum of compact operators gives \(r_{n}\) |
| Rings for algebraic \(K\)-theory | \(M(A)=\mathrm{Mat}_{\mathbb N}(A)\) | Block‑sum of infinite matrices |

Thus **\(M\) is the device that *creates* an additive‑like object even when the ambient category is non‑additive**.

---

### 2 How *M* lets one define \(\eta_{N}\)

For each object \(C\):

1. **Copy:** Start with the canonical inclusions  
   \(\iota_{j}:M(C)\hookrightarrow\bigoplus_{j}M(C)\).

2. **Repeat \(n_{ij}\) times:** Use coproduct injections to view \(n_{ij}\) copies of \(M(C)\) inside the source.

3. **Aggregate:** Apply the natural map \(r_{n_{ij}}\!:\bigvee_{n_{ij}}M(C)\to M(C)\).

4. **Assemble columns:** Compose the resulting maps to land in the \(i^{\text{th}}\) summand of the target.

Because the \(r_{n}\)’s are *natural*, the whole construction is natural in \(C\); assembling the columns gives the required natural transformation \(\eta_{N}\).

Without the \(r_{n}\)-maps none of these “add and land back in a single copy’’ steps are available, so the formula for \(\eta_{N}\) simply cannot be written down in a canonical way.

---

### 3 When can one dispense with *M*?

*If the objects of the original category already carry a compatible additive (or co‑\(H\)) structure*, you can take \(M=\mathrm{Id}\) and define \(\eta_{N}\) directly—this is exactly what happens in abelian categories such as \(R\!\operatorname{-Mod}\) or \(\mathbf{Ch}_{*}(\mathbb Z)\).

In every other context that appears in the thesis (pointed spaces, spectra, \(C^{*}\)-algebras, non‑unital rings, …) the raw objects lack such a structure, so **introducing \(M\) is essential** to:

* make sense of “sum of \(n_{ij}\) copies’’,
* ensure functoriality (the \(\eta_{N}\) maps commute with morphisms),
* guarantee that applying the homological functor \(K\) turns \(\eta_{N}\) into honest matrix multiplication in the target abelian category.

---

### 4 Take‑away

- **Purpose of \(M\):** endow otherwise non‑additive objects with a *functorial* aggregation map, turning “copy‑and‑add’’ into a categorical operation.  
- **Defining \(\eta_{N}\):** requires those aggregation maps; \(M\) supplies them.  
- **When \(M\) can be skipped:** precisely when the category is already additive, in which case \(M=\mathrm{Id}\) and \(\eta_{N}\) reduces to the usual matrix‑with‑integer‑entries map.

Hence the endofunctor \(M\) is not decorative—it is the **minimal extra structure that makes a uniform “matrix multiplication’’ map possible across all the diverse categories the thesis wants to treat simultaneously.**

Below are **five fresh arenas**—none treated in the thesis itself—where the same *matrix → cone → apply‑K* schema works **without modification** once the three standing ingredients are supplied:

| # | Category \(\mathcal C\) | Stabilising endofunctor \(M\) | Example of a homological functor \(K\) | Why the axioms hold |
|---|-------------------------|-------------------------------|----------------------------------------|---------------------|
| 1 | **\(G\)-spectra** (the compactly generated, pointed model for the equivariant stable homotopy category of a finite group \(G\)) | Smash‑suspension by a *representation sphere*: \(M(X)=X\wedge S^{V}\) for any faithful real \(G\)-representation \(V\) | Genuine equivariant homology \(E^{G}_*(-)\) for an \(N_\infty\)–ring spectrum \(E\) | \(S^{V}\) is a *\(G\)-co‑\(H\)-space*; the pinch map \(S^{V}\to S^{V}\vee S^{V}\) and its iterates supply the co‑aggregation maps the thesis calls RP3–RP5. Cones and indexing coproducts exist in \(G\)-spectra, so all hypotheses are met. |
| 2 | **Motivic spaces over a field \(k\)** (pointed simplicial presheaves Nisnevich‑localised, then \(A^{1}\)-inverted) | **\(\mathbb P^{1}\)-suspension:** \(M(X)=X\wedge\mathbb P^{1}\) | \(\mathbf{MGL}\)-homology, motivic cohomology \(\operatorname{H}^{*,*}\), or algebraic cobordism | \(\mathbb P^{1}\) carries the *motivic pinch map* \(\mathbb P^{1}\to\mathbb P^{1}\vee\mathbb P^{1}\). Mapping‑cone/path objects and wedges survive the \(A^{1}\)-local model structure, giving exactly the categorical features the construction needs. |
| 3 | **Stable ∞‑category of perfect complexes \( \mathbf{Perf}(X) \)** on a quasi‑compact, quasi‑separated scheme \(X\) | The *shift* functor: \(M = [1]\) | Negative cyclic homology \(HC^{-}_{*}\), Hochschild homology \(HH_{*}\), or periodic cyclic homology \(HP_{*}\) | \(M=[1]\) already makes every object a graded‑commutative \(\mathbb Z\)-graded *spectrum object*, so finite direct sums and the usual grading morphisms implement the required aggregations. Exact triangles → long exact sequences give the homological axiom. |
| 4 | **Differential‑graded categories** (small, idempotent‑complete DG‑cats over a field) | **Morita‑matrix stabilisation:** \(M(\mathcal A)=\operatorname{Perf}_{dg}(\operatorname{Mat}_{\infty}(\mathcal A))\) | Topological Hochschild homology \(THH_{*}(\mathcal A)\) or topological cyclic homology \(TC_{*}(\mathcal A)\) | Infinite‑matrix completion plays the same role here that \(M_{\infty}(A)\) plays for rings in algebraic \(K\)-theory: block‑sum of matrices is the aggregation map; mapping cones exist in the pre‑triangulated enhancement. |
| 5 | **Module spectra over an \(E_\infty\)-ring \(R\)** (the presentable, symmetric‑monoidal ∞‑category \(\mathbf{Mod}_{R}\)) | The ordinary suspension spectrum functor \(M=\Sigma\) | \(\pi_{*}\) of homotopy groups, or any Landweber‑exact homology \(E_{*}^{R}(-)\) (e.g. \(BP_{*}\), \(MU_{*}\)) | Every suspension spectrum \(\Sigma X\) is a homotopy co‑\(H\)-space, so the pinch map produces co‑aggregations. Exact triangles in \(\mathbf{Mod}_{R}\) are stable and give long exact homology sequences. |

---

## How each new setting meets the thesis’ three ingredients

1. **Existence of mapping‐cone or mapping‐path objects.**  
   All five categories are *stable* (or become so after the usual localisation), hence possess functorial cones and exact triangles.

2. **Endofunctor \(M\) with aggregation / co‑aggregation maps.**  
   *  In (1), (2) and (5) the sphere/pinch or suspension/pinch construction supplies the maps  
      \(\alpha_{n}:M(C)\to\bigvee_{n}M(C)\) required to “add \(n\) copies”.  
   *  In (3) shifts give graded additions; in (4) block‑sum of matrices provides literal additions.

3. **Homological functor \(K\).**  
   Each listed \(K\) turns exact triangles in \(\mathcal C\) into long exact sequences in an abelian category (spectra graded by \(\mathbb Z\) or Mackey functors, abelian groups, etc.), fulfilling the thesis’ *homological* requirement.

Therefore the **matrix‑cone‑apply‑\(K\)** recipe goes through unchanged, yielding “\(K\)-theory with coefficients in an arbitrary abelian group \(G\)” and, by the same proof, a natural **universal‑coefficient exact sequence**

\[
0\longrightarrow G\otimes K_{*}(C)\;\longrightarrow\;KT_{*}(C;G)\;
          \longrightarrow\;\operatorname{Tor}_{1}^{\mathbb Z}(G,K_{*-1}(C))\longrightarrow 0
\]

in *every* one of these new contexts.

---

## What’s genuinely new or useful here?

| Context | Novel phenomena unlocked by adding coefficients |
|---------|-----------------------------------------------|
| **Equivariant \(G\)-spectra** | Produces coefficient‑wise versions of RO(\(G\))-graded homology theories and *equivariant* universal‑coefficient sequences—something normally available only for Mackey‑functor coefficients. |
| **Motivic homotopy** | Gives a *uniform* way to attach finite or mixed‑characteristic coefficient groups to motivic cobordism and motivic cohomology, avoiding ad‑hoc smash‑product constructions with Eilenberg–Mac Lane spectra. |
| **Perfect complexes on schemes** | Extends cyclic-, Hochschild‑ and even \(K\)-theory with coefficients beyond the usual “tensor with \(G\)” trick, covering *singular* schemes where tensor products in complexes behave poorly. |
| **DG categories** | Provides a coefficient‑wise version of \(THH\) and \(TC\), potentially useful in trace‑methods refinements (e.g. Dundas–Goodwillie–McCarthy) for *non‑connective* \(\mathbf{K}\)-theory. |
| **Module spectra over \(E_\infty\)-rings** | Supplies universal‑coefficient sequences for exotic homology theories like \(BP\_*\) and \(MU\_*\) with arbitrary \(G\), a stepping stone toward *chromatic* versions of Brown–Comenetz duality. |

---

### Take‑away

The thesis’ categorical machinery is **portable far beyond** the classical algebraic‐topological settings:

* Any *stable* or *pre‑triangulated* category becomes eligible the moment you can point to an endofunctor \(M\) whose image objects admit coherent “addition of \(n\) copies”.  
* The examples above show that modern ∞‑categorical areas—equivariant, motivic, spectral‑algebraic, and derived‑geometric alike—meet these axioms with only mild, well‑known structures (representation spheres, \(\mathbb P^{1}\), shifts, or matrix stabilisation).  

Hence the thesis does more than generalise known coefficient tricks; it **furnishes a template** that practitioners can drop straight into many current research frontiers, obtaining universal‑coefficient exact sequences and coefficient‑wise versions of their favourite homology theories *for free*.

Below are **two very broad abstract frameworks** that already **contain every concrete case** we have discussed—the thesis’ original list *and* the five additional arenas I proposed (equivariant, motivic, perfect‑complex, DG‑category, and \(E_\infty\)-module examples).  Each framework supplies exactly the three ingredients the thesis needs:

1. a category \(\mathcal C\) with all mapping‑cone or mapping‑path objects;  
2. an endofunctor \(M\) equipped with coherent “aggregation’’ maps \(r_n\);  
3. at least one homological functor \(K\) that sends exact triangles to long exact sequences.

---

## 1 Presentable **symmetric‑monoidal stable ∞‑categories** with a *dualizable cogroup object*

### 1.1 The setting  

* Let \((\mathcal C,\otimes,{\mathbb 1})\) be a **presentable, symmetric‑monoidal, stable ∞‑category** (in Lurie’s sense).  
* Choose an object \(\Sigma\in\mathcal C\) that is  
  * **dualizable** (so tensoring with it preserves colimits), and  
  * equipped with a **coherent pinch map**  
    \[
    \mu\colon\Sigma \longrightarrow \Sigma\oplus\Sigma
    \]
    that turns \(\Sigma\) into a **cogroup object** (a homotopy‑coherent comonoid whose comultiplication is the pinch).

### 1.2 The three thesis ingredients

| Thesis ingredient | Where it comes from in this setting |
|-------------------|--------------------------------------|
| Mapping cones | Any stable ∞‑category has functorial fibres/cofibres \(=\) cones. |
| Endofunctor \(M\) | Define \(M(X)=X\otimes\Sigma\). Iterating \(\mu\) gives natural maps \(r_n : \bigoplus_{n}M(X)\to M(X)\); these satisfy the aggregation axioms (associativity, unitality, symmetry) automatically because \(\Sigma\) is a cogroup object. |
| Homological functor \(K\) | Take any **exact, colimit‑preserving functor** from \(\mathcal C\) to an abelian (or triangulated) target—e.g. homotopy groups \(\pi_{*}\), Borel‑equivariant homology, motivic cohomology, \(BP_{*}\), \(THH_{*}\), etc. Exactness ⇔ sends cofibres to long exact sequences. |

### 1.3 Why this subsumes (almost) everything  

| Concrete example | How it sits inside this framework |
|------------------|-----------------------------------|
| **Classical spectra** | \(\mathcal C=\mathbf{Sp}\), \(\Sigma=S^{1}\) (or any fixed sphere) |
| **\(G\)-spectra** for finite \(G\) | \(\mathcal C=\mathbf{Sp}^{G}\), \(\Sigma=S^{V}\) for a faithful representation \(V\) |
| **Motivic spectra** over a field \(k\) | \(\mathcal C=\mathbf{Sp}^{\mathbb{A}^{1}}\), \(\Sigma=\mathbb P^{1}\) |
| **Module spectra** over an \(E_\infty\)-ring \(R\) | \(\mathcal C=\mathbf{Mod}_{R}\), \(\Sigma=S^{1}\) |
| **Topological \(K\)-theory of \(C^{*}\)-algebras** | Work in the *presentable* symmetric‑monoidal localisation of \(C^{*}\)-algebras by stabilisation; \(\Sigma=\mathbb K\) (the compacts) acts by \(M(A)=A\widehat\otimes\mathbb K\). |

The only thesis examples not literally stable already (e.g. pointed CW complexes) embed via the suspension‑spectrum functor \( \Sigma^\infty_+\colon \mathbf{Top}_*\to\mathbf{Sp}\); one simply performs the construction in \(\mathbf{Sp}\) and restricts along this fully faithful embedding.

---

## 2 Small **idempotent‑complete stable ∞‑categories** with “matrix‑stabilisation’’  

### 2.1 The setting  

* Let \(\mathcal C\) be a **small, idempotent‑complete, stable ∞‑category.**  
* Form the categorical *Ind‑completion* \(\operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal C)\)—a presentable stable ∞‑category that contains \(\mathcal C\) as the sub‑category of compact objects.  
* Inside \(\operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal C)\) take the **countable coproduct** endofunctor  

  \[
  M(X)\;=\;\bigoplus_{n\in\mathbb N} X .
  \]

  (Think of \(M\) as the “infinite matrix’’ analogue \(M_\infty(-)\).)

### 2.2 The thesis ingredients  

| Ingredient | Source |
|------------|--------|
| Mapping cones | Both \(\mathcal C\) and \(\operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal C)\) are stable ∞‑categories. |
| Endofunctor \(M\) | The countable coproduct functor exists because \(\operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal C)\) is presentable.  The obvious fold maps \(r_n : \bigoplus_{n}M(X)\to M(X)\) satisfy the aggregation axioms. |
| Homological functor \(K\) | Any **localising invariant** of small stable ∞‑categories—e.g. non‑connective \(K\)-theory, Hochschild or cyclic homology, topological Hochschild homology—extends to \(\operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal C)\) by preservation of filtered colimits and turns exact triangles into long exact sequences. |

### 2.3 Examples encompassed  

| Original arena | Realisation in this framework |
|----------------|-------------------------------|
| **Chain complexes / derived categories** | \(\mathcal C=\mathbf{Perf}_{\mathbb Z}\) (or \(\mathbf{Perf}_{R}\)); \(M\) becomes the shift \([1]\) *or* the countable‑coproduct functor. |
| **DG categories** | Each small DG‑cat \(\mathcal A\) yields a small stable ∞‑category under the dg‑nerve; matrix stabilisation \(M(\mathcal A)=\operatorname{Perf}_{dg}(\operatorname{Mat}_{\infty}\mathcal A)\) is a *model* for the countable coproduct endofunctor. |
| **Perfect complexes on a scheme** \(X\) | \(\mathcal C=\mathbf{Perf}(X)\). |
| **Non‑unital rings and algebraic \(K\)-theory** | Let \(\mathcal C\) be the *idempotent‑complete* stable ∞‑category of perfect \(A\)-modules; \(M=\bigoplus_\mathbb N\) models the usual \(M_\infty(A)\). |

---

## 3 How these frameworks *swallow* the construction

Within either framework the **matrix–cone–apply‑\(K\)** procedure works verbatim:

1. **Define \(\eta_{N}\)** using the aggregation maps \(r_n\) (obtained either from the cogroup object in Framework 1 or from finite‑/countable‑coproducts in Framework 2).  
2. **Form the mapping cone/path**—functorial because the categories are stable.  
3. **Apply the exact functor \(K\)**—yielding long exact sequences and hence the universal‑coefficient short exact sequence that identifies \(KT^{m}(-;G)\) with the classical “tensor ⊕ Tor’’ recipe whenever that recipe exists.

No extra axioms or case‑by‑case arguments are needed; all earlier concrete examples are just **instantiations** of one of these two blueprints.

---

## 4 Why two frameworks—and not one?

*Framework 1* covers every situation where the stabilising gadget is **multiplicative** (smash‑product with a sphere, tensoring with \(\mathbb K\), etc.).  
*Framework 2* takes over when stabilisation is **additive in nature** (block‑sum of matrices, countable coproducts, shifts) and the category is inherently *small* or *idempotent‑complete* rather than presentable‑and‑monoidal.

While it is conceivable to weld the two together in a single mega‑axiom scheme, keeping them separate makes it transparent which structural feature—**tensoring** versus **coproduct‑completion**—is responsible for the aggregation maps that drive the matrix construction.

---

### Take‑away

> *“Once you can work inside any stable ∞‑category that is either symmetric‑monoidal with a cogroup object, or compact‑generated by its own countable coproducts, the thesis’ coefficient machine drops in for free.”*

That single observation unites:

* **classical algebraic topology** (spectra and their variants),  
* **operator‑algebraic settings** (via \(\mathbb K\)-stabilisation),  
* **algebraic and motivic geometry** (perfect complexes, motivic spectra), and  
* **non‑commutative geometry** (DG categories, \(THH\), \(TC\), \(K\)-theory).

Put differently, *most* contemporary homological‑invariant factories already live inside one of these two enormous umbrellas, so the thesis’ recipe becomes a **universal “add coefficients’’ button** applicable across large swaths of current mathematics.

### 0  What the thesis + Frameworks (1) & (2) actually cover  

All constructions we have discussed up to now share **three structural features**:

| Requirement | Where it comes from |
|-------------|--------------------|
| (i) a category with *functorial* cones (so exact triangles/long exact sequences); | supplied by stability, or at least a cone–path calculus; |
| (ii) a *single, object‑independent* abelian coefficient group \(G\); | encoded by a presentation matrix \(N\) and realised through the endofunctor \(M\); |
| (iii) an endofunctor \(M\) whose image objects admit coherent aggregation maps \(r_n\). |   **Framework 1:** \(M=-\otimes\Sigma\) with \(\Sigma\) a cogroup object; **Framework 2:** \(M=\bigoplus_\mathbb N\) (matrix stabilisation). |

Whenever **any one** of those three fails, the matrix–cone recipe stops working.  
Below are **four broad families of “homology with coefficients’’ that break at least one condition and therefore lie outside both Framework 1 and Framework 2**.

---

## 1 *Twisted* ordinary (co)homology with **local coefficient systems**

*Example.*  Singular homology \(H_n(X;\,L)\) where \(L\) is a local system of abelian groups classified by a representation \(\pi_1(X)\to\operatorname{Aut}(A)\).

* **Why it is outside.**  
  *Condition (ii) fails.*  The coefficient data is *not constant*—\(L\) varies functorially *with* \(X\).  
  There is no single presentation matrix \(N\) in the source category, hence no global natural transformation \(\eta_N\) to take its cone.  
  More formally, the local‑system functor \(X\mapsto L_X\) lands in the *slice* topos over \(X\), so the assignment \(X\mapsto H_n(X;L_X)\) cannot be expressed as “apply a fixed homological functor, then tensor with a fixed group”.

* **Consequence.**  Universal‑coefficient short exact sequences survive, but their derivation uses *twisted* chain complexes, not the thesis’ matrix trick.

---

## 2 Equivariant theories with **orbit‑wise coefficient systems**  
(Bredon homology, RO(\(G\))-graded cohomology with a Mackey‑ or Green‑functor coefficient)

*Example.*  For a \(G\)-space \(Y\) and a Mackey functor \(\underline M\), Bredon homology \(H_*^G(Y;\,\underline M)\).

* **Why it is outside.**  
  Even in a stable equivariant ∞‑category, \(\underline M\) lives **in the target**, not as a single global object of the *source* category.  
  There is no canonical endofunctor \(M\) on \(\mathbf{Sp}^G\) whose image objects carry aggregation maps valued in \(\underline M\).  
  In particular the natural map “multiply by a matrix” cannot be written without fixing an orbit, so \(\eta_N\) is not available.

* **Consequence.**  Bredon/Mackey coefficients are handled via *enriched* homological algebra (spectra of coefficient systems), not by the thesis’ constant‑\(G\) cone device.

---

## 3 **Twisted generalised cohomology** (e.g. topological \(K^*(X,\alpha)\), \(TMF\)-twists, differential‑cohomology twists)

*Example.*  A bundle gerbe \(\alpha\in H^{3}(X;\mathbb Z)\) defines twisted \(K\)-theory groups \(K^*(X,\alpha)\).

* **Why it is outside.**  
  *Both* Condition (ii) and (iii) break:

  *  The coefficient object is *not an abelian group* but a **bundle of spectra** or **module spectrum** varying with \(X\).  
  *  There is no endofunctor \(M\) whose image carries a uniform aggregation map compatible with every possible twist \(\alpha\).

  Twisted theories are built by **parametrised spectra**; the data live in the *parameter* rather than the *coefficient group* slot.

---

## 4 Functors based on **non‑abelian coefficients or crossed‑module actions**

*Examples.*  
  * First homology \(H_1(X;G)\) for **non‑abelian** \(G\) (defined via crossed homomorphisms).  
  * Non‑abelian group cohomology \(H^1(\pi;G)\) classifying principal \(G\)-bundles.

* **Why it is outside.**  
  The thesis assumes \(\operatorname{coker}N\) is an **abelian group** so that tensor and Tor make sense.  
  Non‑abelian targets lack a well‑behaved notion of “tensor product with the homology object”, and mapping cones in the source category do not linearise the necessary crossed‑module structures.

---

### A quick diagram of the landscape

```
                ┌────────────────────────────────────┐
                │ Thesis + Frameworks 1 & 2          │
                │  (constant abelian G, uniform M)   │
                └────────────────────────────────────┘
                           ▲            ▲
          fail (ii)       /              \        fail (iii)
             local       /                \     no uniform M
        coefficient sys.                    twisted gen. coh.
       (π₁‑actions, L)                     (K^*(X,α), TMF_tw)
                          X
                          | fail (abelian G)
                          ↓
                non‑abelian / crossed‑module coeffs.
```

---

## Take‑away  

*The thesis’ machinery is extremely broad*—any **stable** (or cone‑calculus) setting with a single, object‑independent abelian group \(G\) and an endofunctor \(M\) that supplies aggregation maps is in scope.

**It misses exactly those coefficient theories where at least one of those three pillars collapses:**

1. **Coefficient object varies with the input** (local systems, Bredon/Mackey functors).  
2. **Coefficient object needs extra structure** not obtainable via a global matrix presentation (twisted spectra, gerbes, differential refinements).  
3. **Coefficient object is non‑abelian**, so the universal‑coefficient sequence—and hence the whole “matrix → cone → tensor/Tor’’ ideology—has no meaning.

These families of functors with coefficients therefore **cannot** be produced by the thesis’ method and do **not** embed in either of the two unifying frameworks we outlined.
Where can I find out more about these three examples of coefficient theories that are not captured by the thesis framework?

parts:
Below is a compact “where‑to‑look‑next” guide for the three families of coefficient theories that lie **outside** the thesis mechanism and the two unifying frameworks I sketched earlier.  For each family I list   

* **Entry points** – gentle sources or short survey notes;  
* **Core texts** – thorough book‑length treatments;  
* **Current research & survey papers** – if you want to see how the field is evolving right now.  

---

## 1  Local‑system (twisted) homology & cohomology  

| Tier | Recommended source | Why it helps |
|------|--------------------|-------------|
| *Entry* | A. Hatcher, *Algebraic Topology*, §3.H “Homology with Local Coefficients” citeturn11search0 | Minimal prerequisites; works through definitions and Poincaré duality in ~20 pp. |
|        | Math StackExchange thread “Sources on twisted/local (co)homology” – crowdsourced bibliography citeturn1view0 | Quick annotated list of lecture notes & papers if you need alternatives to Hatcher. |
| *Core* | Banyaga–Hurtubise–Spaeth, **Twisted Morse Complexes** (LNM 2361, Springer 2024) citeturn8view0 | Modern, rigorous 130‑page text: builds Morse (co)homology with arbitrary local systems and proves a twisted Morse Homology Theorem. |
|        | May–Sigurdsson, **Parametrized Homotopy Theory** (AMS 2006) – Chap. 23 ff. on bundles of spectra citeturn5view0 | Puts local systems into the broader fibrewise‑spectra language used in twisted generalised (co)homology. |
| *Research* | Papers on twisted Morse & Novikov homology (see citations inside *Twisted Morse Complexes*), and on sheaf‑theoretic approaches to Poincaré duality (e.g. arXiv:1709.00569). | Current refinements and applications. |

---

## 2  Equivariant (Bredon / Mackey‑functor) homology  

| Tier | Recommended source | Why it helps |
|------|--------------------|-------------|
| *Entry* | Arun Debray, **Equivariant Homotopy Theory** lecture notes (31 pp.) – §4 on Bredon chains citeturn6search8 | Concise derivation of Bredon (co)homology and first computations. |
| *Core* | J. P. May, **Equivariant Homotopy and Cohomology Theory** (CBMS 91, AMS 1996) – Chaps. I, IV, IX – XIII citeturn9view0 | The standard 400‑page reference: formal axioms, Mackey functors, RO(G)‑grading, Smith theory, universal coefficient spectral sequences. |
|        | Elmendorf–Kriz–May–Mandell, *Rings, Modules, and Algebras in Stable Homotopy Theory* (esp. Part I) – for Mackey‑functor actions on spectra. | Bridges from classical Bredon theory to modern equivariant stable homotopy. |
| *Research* | Y. Jain, “Bredon Equivariant Homology of Representation Spheres” citeturn0search1; Greenlees & others on RO(G)‑graded calculations; arXiv:1405.1770 on Mackey‑valued cohomology. | Worked computations and new RO(G) tools. |

---

## 3  Twisted generalised (spectral) cohomology  

| Tier | Recommended source | Why it helps |
|------|--------------------|-------------|
| *Entry* | nLab articles **“twisted K‑theory”** and **“twisted cohomology”** – encyclopaedic definitions & examples citeturn4search9turn7search0 | Snapshot of terminology, model‑categories vs ∞‑categories viewpoints, and physics links. |
| *Core* | **Freed–Hopkins–Teleman** trilogy *Loop Groups and Twisted K‑Theory* I–III (2007–2011) – foundations + deep application to the Verlinde ring citeturn4search0turn4search2 | Definitive reference for topological twisted K‑theory and its equivariant flavours. |
|        | **Ando–Blumberg–Gepner**, “Twists of K‑theory and TMF” (arXiv:1002.3004) – stable‑homotopy/∞‑categorical treatment of twists for any multiplicative theory citeturn10view0 | Extends the Freed–Hopkins picture to elliptic cohomology & TMF. |
|        | May–Sigurdsson, **Parametrized Homotopy Theory** – Chap. 23 on bundles of spectra and twisted (co)homology citeturn5view0 | Universal construction of *spectral bundle* twists; background for modern work on differential‑refined twists. |
| *Research* | Nikolaus–Sachse–Schreiber, “Twisted Differential Cohomology” (2013 → 2020 version) citeturn7search5; arXiv:2407.xxxx series on **Real‑twisted K‑theory** citeturn6search6. | Shows how differential refinements and degree‑four twists enter string‑theoretic applications. |

---

### How to navigate these resources

1. **Skim an entry‑level source** to fix notation (local systems ↔ local coefficient bundles; Mackey‑functor coefficients; Picard‑∞‑groupoids for twists).  
2. **Consult the core text** for the formal machinery, universal coefficient or spectral‑sequence tools, and worked computations.  
3. **Dip into the research articles** once you need explicit modern computations or the ∞‑categorical formalism.

All three families have active communities: look for recent preprints on arXiv under **math.AT** (Algebraic Topology) tagged “twisted”, “equivariant”, or “Mackey functor” to stay current.

Without these structures, the construction of such functors may become less structured or lose certain desirable properties, like compatibility with the tensor operation.
